item.title: Quantum at the SIGPLAN Track at PLDI 2022
item.description:
Two previously published quantum PL papers will have in-person talks during the SIGPLAN Track at PLDI 2022:

  • PLDI 2021: Quantum Abstract Interpretation by Nengkun Yu, Jens Palsberg
  • POPL 2021: A Verified Optimizer for Quantum Circuits by Kesha Hietala, Robert Rand, Shih-Han Hung, Xiaodi Wu, Michael Hicks

item.title: Quantum at PLDI 2022
item.description:
There are three interesting quantum PL and verification related papers being presented at PLDI 2022:

  • Algebraic Reasoning of Quantum Programs via Non-Idempotent Kleene Algebra by Yuxiang Peng, Mingsheng Ying, Xiaodi Wu
  • Giallar: Push-button Verification for the Qiskit Quantum Compiler by Runzhou Tao, Yunong Shi, Jianan Yao, Xupeng Li, Ali Javadi-Abhari, Andrew W. Cross, Frederic T. Chong, Ronghui Gu
  • Quartz: Superoptimization of Quantum Circuits by Mingkuan Xu, Zikun Li, Oded Padon, Sina Lin, Jessica Pointing, Auguste Hirth, Henry Ma, Jens Palsberg, Alex Aiken, Umut A. Acar, Zhihao Jia

All of these papers are available through the bibliography.

item.title: Algebraic Reasoning of Quantum Programs via Non-Idempotent Kleene Algebra
item.description: PLDI ‘22. See arXiv for extended version. To appear at PLDI 2022

item.title: Giallar: Push-Button Verification for the Qiskit Quantum Compiler
item.description: PLDI ‘22. Previously known as CertiQ (arXiv:1908.08963). To appear at PLDI 2022

item.title: Quartz: Superoptimization of Quantum Circuits
item.description: PLDI ‘22. Previously known as Quanto. To appear at PLDI 2022.

Quantum at POPL 2022
item.description:
There are four interesting quantum PL and verification related papers being presented at POPL 2022:

  • Quantum Information Effects by Robin Kaarsgaard, Chris Heunen
  • Twist: Sound Reasoning for Purity and Entanglement in Quantum Programs by Charles Yuan, Christopher McNally, Michael Carbin
  • Quantum Separation Logic: A Framework for Local Reasoning of Quantum Programs by Xuan-Bach Le, Jun Sun, Shang-Wei Lin, David Sanan
  • Semantics for Variational Quantum Programming by Xiaodong Jia, Andre Kornell, Bert Lindenhovius, Michael Mislove, Vladimir Zamdzhiev

All of these papers have been added to bibliography including their appendices and expanded versions for your convenience:

item.title: A Quantum Interpretation of Separating Conjunction for Local Reasoning of Quantum Programs Based on Separation Logic
Quantum Information Effects
Semantics for Variational Quantum Programming
Twist: Sound Reasoning for Purity and Entanglement in Quantum Programs
item.description: POPL ‘22. Also see the associated appendix.

item.title: A Quantum PL Pronunciation Guide
item.description:
Project Name Pronounced as
IQu haiku
LIQ$Ui|\rangle$ liquid
OpenQASM open chasm
PLanQC plank / Planck
PyQuil pie-quill
PyZX pizzix (like physics)
Q# Q-Sharp
QASM chasm
Qbricks Q-bricks / Kubrick’s
Qiskit kiss-kit AND quiss-kit1
Quil quill
QWIRE choir
Silq silk
SQIR squire
t$|$ket$\rangle$ ticket
VOQC vox
ZX zed ex

Bonus: Michael Nielsen and Isaac Chuang’s classic textbook Quantum Computation and Quantum Information is affectionately known as Mike and Ike.

  1. Source: How Do You Pronounce “Qiskit?"; also see an older tweet from the official Qiskit account. ↩︎

item.title: End of Year 2021 Updates
item.description:
Since the last news item in July, there have been several visual and usability improvements to this QPL Bib. I list the major ones here:

  • The menu bar of the site includes several new pages:
    • an About page
    • two indices:
      • Authors sorted alphabetically
      • Keywords/Tags sorted by both usage and alphabetically
    • two other renderings of the same bibliography:
      • Retro (generated by bibtex2html)
      • BibBase
  • We now have a tag cloud at the bottom of the home page.
  • The bibliography has grown to almost 125 publications! We started with just about 50.
  • Apart from old papers, I continue to add preprints of papers at upcoming conferences as soon as they become available. An example.
  • We have a new short URL: git.io/qpl-bib.
  • There is a new Contributing Guide.
  • There is some progress on grouping papers by subareas:
    • a new publication type for software.
    • two new categories:
      • Surveys
      • PhD Dissertations
  • Various other issues tracked on GitHub have been resolved.
  • The bibentries themselves have been normalized in several ways.
  • We have a new site favicon courtesy of lastspark from the Noun Project.

Other minor changes get incorporated as I notice issues (see GitHub). Your contributions are most welcome as usual.

Thanks to Robert Rand, Mingsheng Ying, Dongho Lee, Matt Amy, and Sam Staton for their suggestions in helping improve this community resource.

I wish everyone a Happy New Year 2022!

item.title: About
item.description:
Welcome to Quantum Programming Languages & Verification Bibliography (aka qpl-bib). The goal of this site is to provide the quantum PL and verification community with canonical bibliographic entries that we can easily import in our papers. The emphasis is on:

  1. correct data for all bib entries and each of their fields;
  2. being comprehensive in including all relevant metadata;
  3. providing URLs to expanded versions and/or legal copies (such as author copy, arXiv preprints, etc.) for non-open access publications; and
  4. being easily navigable and searchable on the web interface.

This project was started by Kartik, a PhD student in Quantum PL, while attending his advisor Robert Rand’s seminar on the subject in Spring 2021. Contributions from the community are most welcome. See our contributing guide.

Other resources:

  • A rendering of this bib database using bibtex2html (linked in navigation menu as Retro).
  • A rendering using BibBase (NOTE: Some entries seem to be missing in this render.).
  • An external bibliography of ZX-calculus publications.

We hope you find this community resource useful. If you have any questions or comments, please don’t hesitate to contact Kartik.

The site icon is quantum computer by lastspark from the Noun Project.

GitHub Org and Better UI
item.description:
During our last weekly meeting, Robert and I came up with the idea of presenting the QPL bibliography that I have been maintaining at http://ks.cs.uchicago.edu/qpl-bib/ in a better way.

So I decided to move the GitHub repo to its own organization and set up this Hugo-based website to present publications with many filtering options. One can also click on an author’s name to see just their publications.

I will consider moving the older bibtex2html-based bibliography somewhere here as well.

EDIT (2021-09-30): See the Retro link in the navigation bar for bibtex2html rendering.
